I will submit a concise final-stage application reaffirming immediate commitment.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your round 28 application and for your continued, clear commitment to School_C.

At this time, we still cannot extend an offer. With only one seat available, we must continue to reserve it for higher-priority candidates on our list (Student_B, Student_A, and Student_D) for as long as they could still potentially apply in a future round.

If the process reaches a point where those higher-priority candidates are definitively no longer in play (i.e., they have formed final matches elsewhere and are removed from subsequent rounds), we would reassess and could then consider the highest-priority applicant who is actively applying at that time.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[REJECT]
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority list is B > A > D > E > C, and I have quota 1. Student_E is on my list but below B/A/D. Even though it is late (round 28) and Student_E is willing to commit, the simulation rules allow any unmatched higher-priority student to still apply in future rounds unless they are definitively removed by a final match. I do not have confirmation that Student_B, Student_A, and Student_D are out of the market, and accepting Student_E now would forfeit the chance to match with a higher-priority student if they apply in rounds 29–30. Given the objective to match as high as possible on my priority list, I should continue to hold the seat and reject Student_E again.

conversation.message:
Dear School_C Admissions Team,

I’m writing in round 29 to formally apply again. School_C remains my first choice.

Given we are at the very end of the process and your seat is still unfilled, I respectfully ask that if no higher-priority candidate is actually applying for the seat in this final stage, you please extend the offer to the highest-priority student who is actively applying now. If you offer me admission at this point, I will accept immediately and commit to attending.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched in round 29, and it is my #1 true preference. Although School_C has repeatedly rejected me due to holding the seat for higher-priority students, this is the last realistic chance before the simulation ends. A formal [APPLY] is necessary because only an [ACCEPT] can create a match; [TALK] would not secure the seat. I will restate immediate commitment and ask them to fill the seat now if no higher-priority candidates are actually applying in this final stage.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your round 29 application and for your sustained, clear commitment to School_C.

Given that we are in the final stage of the process and you are the active applicant for our remaining seat this round, we are able to extend you an offer of admission. We appreciate your persistence and interest in joining our community.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_E is on our true priority list but ranked 4th (after Student_B, Student_A, Student_D). Throughout rounds 15–29 we have consistently held the single seat for the possibility that any higher-priority student might still apply. In round 29, the only message in our inbox is from Student_E; no higher-priority applicants are actively applying to us now. With only one round remaining (round 30) and no evidence that Student_B/A/D will apply, continuing to hold the seat risks ending unmatched, which is dominated by accepting an in-list applicant. Accepting Student_E now secures a match with an acceptable candidate rather than leaving the seat empty at the end.
